results.name: Aboriginal History Archive
results.description: The Aboriginal History Archive at Victoria University, led by Gary Foley, is dedicated to the collection and preservation of First Peoples' stories and cultural material. The political activism of the Black Power movement in the 1970s is intersected with representation of Aboriginal actors on screen.

key_work.title: Aboriginal History Archive
key_work.brief_description: The Aboriginal History Archive is Australia’s first collection of resources that documents the Black Power movement, resists colonial narratives and celebrates self-determination. Activists of the era saw the power of film and TV to tell truth, advocate for justice and resist oppression.

end.title: Dogs in Space
end.brief_description: Melbourne, Australia 1978. The punk phenomenon is sweeping the country and Dogs In Space, a punk group, are part of it. A ragtag collection of outcasts live in a squat, surviving on a diet of old TV space films, drugs and good music.

constellations_other.name: Jill Bilcock
constellations_other.description: An editor’s work often goes unnoticed, but their scene-stitching not only brings the director’s vision to life but sometimes steals the show. One of Australia’s greatest editors, Jill Bilcock, has shaped some of the country’s most memorable screen stories.

start.title: The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith
start.creator_credit: Fred Schepisi, Bruce Finlayson, The Film House, Victorian Film and Wendy Dickson

video_links.name: The Chant Of Jimmie Blacksmith Trailer

start.brief_description: In the late 1970s, non-Indigenous filmmakers wanting to support Indigenous Rights in Australia released films on Black Australia to mixed success. Fred Schepisi’s controversial The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith (1978) divided audiences and demonstrated how non-Indigenous storytellers could co-opt Indigenous stories to great detriment.

end.brief_description: From the cops and the crocs of 1960s Palm Island to the blood-spattered dance floors of Melbourne in the 70s, Wrong Kind of Black is the personal story of Boori Monty Pryor (Clarence Ryan) and his brother Paul (Aaron McGrath).

constellations_other.description: Comedy has been used by First Nations storytellers as a tool for social change. On our screens, humour invites audiences to engage with stories and prompts them to grapple with ideas that they otherwise might shy away from.

links.description: Tom E Lewis also appeared in the TV series Wrong Kind of Black (2018), a comedy-drama about an Aboriginal DJ in Melbourne’s disco scene of the 1970s, narrated by and based on the life of author Boori Monty Pryor.

constellations_other.name: Black Power through film and TV
constellations_other.description: The Black Power movement of the late 1960s and early 70s was “the most exciting and dynamic era in modern Indigenous history” according to Aboriginal activist Professor Gary Foley, who gained widespread attention for protests during the time and later leveraged film and TV to fight for Indigenous rights.

end.brief_description: Redfern Now is a kaleidoscopic drama that explores this inner-city suburb and the people who inhabit it. The highly celebrated and multi award-winning drama series written, directed and produced by Indigenous creatives.

constellations_other.name: Jedda: Uneven ground, the road to on-screen diversity
constellations_other.description: Jedda was the first fully funded Australian feature to be shot on colour film. It was also the first Australian film with Aboriginal actors in lead roles, however, it reflects a deeply problematic time in Australian history.

constellations_other.name: The secret life of suburbia and music videos
constellations_other.description: Australia's famous streets and suburbs have defined music videos, TV shows and miniseries, providing a unique backdrop to Australian stories and music.

constellations_other.name: Landscape as character
constellations_other.description: The landscape is often a character in Australian films. Usually, it's a villain that represents our problematic national character and is increasingly used to challenge our troubled history and explore our evolving identities.

constellations_other.name: Canopy
constellations_other.description: John Harvey is a Torres Strait Islander producer, director and writer in screen and stage whose work Canopy celebrates Indigenous self-representation.

links.description: Lisa Flanagan appeared alongside Tom E. Lewis in Wrong Kind of Black (2018) and is well known for her roles on Australian screen, including in Redfern Now (2012–15), following the lives of contemporary Aboriginal Australians in the Sydney suburb of Redfern.

results.name: Painting pictures
results.description: Painter and photographer Louis Le Prince was inspired to develop the technology to make animated pictures by the circular panoramic paintings of his friends. His films captured everyday life and alluded to his artistic vision for cinema.

key_work.title: Louis Le Prince

results.name: News on location
results.description: The Pye Orthicon is an example of the type of television cameras used from the 1950s in Australia for both studio and outside broadcast work. Such cameras did not have have the capacity to record while out on location and so outside crews would transmit vision and sound back to studios for recording or live broadcast.

key_work.title: Type 2014K Image Orthicon camera
key_work.creator_credit: Films & Equipment Ltd., PYE Ltd. and Vinten
key_work.brief_description: Pye cameras were used across Australia in newsrooms and in the field by journalists at GTV9 and ABV2. They are lightweight and compact, making them easy to transport, and they feature an extended focus range switch for extreme close-ups.

NAGRA Reel to Reel Tape Recorder

Nagra, Switzerland, c. 1970s

Courtesy Paul Huntingford
end.brief_description: “Sound is what truly convinces the mind it is in a place,” said videogame designer Jesse Schell. “In other words, hearing is believing.” Sound is an essential part of storytelling, whether it’s ambient noise, roaring sound effects or a musical score swelling over the action. It helps communicate what’s happening, not just in narrative features and television but also in documentaries, news programmes and commercials. One of the items displayed here is a vintage Nagra audio tape recorder used by Channel 7 News in Sydney during the 1960s and early 1970s when external news footage was shot on 16mm reversal film. The syncing of sound and vision occurred back in the editing room before going to air.

results.name: Black documentary and truth telling
results.description: Essie Coffey was a trailblazer of Indigenous filmmaking, being the first Aboriginal woman to direct a documentary. The film spotlights the outspoken voice Coffey utilised to convey the realities faced by Aboriginal people and to encourage resistance to assimilation.

key_work.title: My Survival as an Aboriginal
key_work.credit_line:
From the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia – NFSA Restores Collection
Courtesy Ballad Films
key_work.brief_description:
“I wanted to show that we have and will continue to survive white invasion.”

Essie Coffey’s camera zooms in on the thin lips of a white teacher telling a class of Aboriginal students that Captain Cook ‘discovered’ Australia. The students gaze back, their eyes becoming the focus, fed up with the narratives that erase the true history of invasion and Aboriginal sovereignty taught in schools.

My Survival as an Aboriginal shows the reality of life for Essie’s community in Brewarrina, while simultaneously calling into question the fantasies perpetuated by non-Indigenous voyeurs; she staunchly refused to assimilate.

Essie pushed boundaries in her everyday life and in her artmaking. She made this uncompromising documentary film in 1978 at a time when opportunities for women filmmakers were few and far between, let alone for Indigenous women filmmakers.

By recording her own life and amplifying her voice, Essie gave future generations of First Nations truthtellers their own voice, inspiring a movement of films that showed Aboriginal life in a way that challenged racism and injustice, and imagine a better future unbound from white control.

end.brief_description: Rick is a mentally-unbalanced but scientifically gifted old man who has recently reconnected with his family. He spends most of his time involving his young grandson Morty in dangerous, outlandish adventures throughout space and alternate universes. Compounded with Morty’s already unstable family life, these events cause Morty much distress at home and school.

links.description: Originating from an animated parody of Back to the Future, Rick and Morty is a sci-fi sitcom that follows an eccentric mad scientist Rick and his naïve yet kindly grandson Morty. results.name: Broadcasting marginal voices
results.description: The creation of Indigenous broadcasting in Central Australia from the late 1970s meant an array of diverse Black stories could be shared. Today, important stories told by those who physically and metaphorically live on the margins can be broadcast widely.

key_work.title: Birth of Indigenous broadcasting
key_work.brief_description: From the 1970s, Aboriginal Elders in Central Australia were concerned that satellite TV could potentially bring non-Indigenous stories to remote Aboriginal communities. In response, several Aboriginal media organisations broadcast local content via videotape and pirate TV, leading to the eventual establishment of Indigenous broadcasters.

results.name: Shadow play
results.description: Shadow play uses light and projection to tell stories – fundamentals that would evolve into cinematography. In the Wayang tradition, gunungan open and close performances and indicate scene changes and the puppets pass across the projection screen in a similar way to a wipe transition.

key_work.title: Shadow Play [interactive]
key_work.brief_description: The discovery of fire not only banished the darkness and provided warmth to our ancestors, it also allowed them to shape their imagination by projecting shadows, which visitors can do at the entrance to The Story of the Moving Image.

constellations_other.name: Shadow play
constellations_other.description: Shadow play uses light and projection to tell stories – fundamentals that would evolve into cinematography. In the Wayang tradition, gunungan open and close performances and indicate scene changes and the puppets pass across the projection screen in a similar way to a wipe transition.

links.description: First used by Robert Paul in 1901, the wipe transitional effect was used throughout the silent era and into the 1930’s as a method of propelling the pace of scenes. Within Flying to Rio, horizontal wipes are used to add momentum and heighten comedy while attention passes between multiple characters.

links.description: Horizontal wipes were again popularized in the 1970s with The Sting, again ultilised as a method of increasing the pace of action. The heist film, set in the 1930s, also uses title cards to create distinct chapters of the narrative as well as a nod to early cinema.

end.brief_description: Brimming with action while incisively examining the nature of truth, “Rashomon” is perhaps the finest film ever to investigate the philosophy of justice. Through an ingenious use of camera and flashbacks, Kurosawa reveals the complexities of human nature as four people recount different versions of the story of a man’s murder and the rape of his wife.

links.description: George Lucas was inspired to use wipes in his Star Wars films by Akira Kurosawa. This form of cinematic punctuation is closely tied to the Japanese director who himself was inspired by films of the silent era which employed wipes for visual effect and pace.

results.name: Into a world of colour
results.description: Filmmakers have been using colour as a method of storytelling since the first moving pictures. Colour can be used to signify emotion, intensify drama or to create a strong visual aesthetic.

key_work.title: Into a World of Colour
key_work.brief_description: Since the beginning of cinema, filmmakers experimented with colour and sound by hand-tinting frames and providing orchestral accompaniments. But it wasn’t until the early 20th century that ‘talkies’ truly changed the industry and glorious Technicolor ushered in the first golden age of cinema.

links.description: Alfred Hitchcock uses the evocative symbolism of saturated colours in Vertigo to give greater insight into the narrative. Red and green are heavily contrasted between the main characters: red represents caution and danger for Scottie while green embodies illusion and desire for Madeline.

results.name: Australians on the world stage
results.description: George Miller’s Mad Max revolutionised movies when it tore through cinemas in 1979. Max Rockatansky’s journey dispensing justice across the wasteland in his V8 Interceptor became a cult classic and catapulted Australian cinema onto the world stage.

key_work.title: The Mad Max film series
key_work.brief_description: George Miller’s Mad Max revolutionised movies when it tore through cinemas in 1979. Mad Max’s super-powered vehicles, legendary characters and post-apocalyptic setting influenced everything from movies, manga and music videos to fashion, videogames and art, spawning enough parodies, homages and clones to fill a Thunderdome.

end.brief_description: The piano used in Jane Campion’s award-winning classic dates from 1825–30 and was shipped to the New Zealand from London. Two replicas were made – a lightweight version that could be carried through the bush and one with a steel frame for underwater scenes.

links.description: There’s a reason Australia adopts talented New Zealanders as their own and you only need to look at director Jane Campion to see why. Campion’s The Piano nabbed three Academy Awards, while the Emmy and Golden Globe-nominated Top of the Lake reunited Campion with Holly Hunter and starred Elizabeth Moss.

end.brief_description: The piano used in Jane Campion’s award-winning classic dates from 1825–30 and was shipped to the New Zealand from London. Two replicas were made – a lightweight version that could be carried through the bush and one with a steel frame for underwater scenes.

constellations_primary.name: When music speaks
constellations_primary.description: Some characters or moments are expressed more intensely through a musical motif than dialogue or action.

constellations_other.description: From an independent Sydney cinema to the world's stage, Jan Chapman's work has many connections to the Australian film scene and Hollywood.

links.description: Like Judy Davis, My Brilliant Career‘s other star, Sam Neil, went on to enjoy an acclaimed international career. Fourteen years after, in the same year he starred in Jurassic Park, Neil appeared alongside Holly Hunter in Jane Campion’s The Piano.

start.title: Saw
start.creator_credit: James Wan, Jennifer L. Soulages, Gregg Hoffman, Mark Burg, Oren Koules, Evolution Entertainment, Lionsgate, Saw Productions Inc., Twisted Pictures, Julie Berghoff and Leigh Whannell
start.brief_description: Obsessed with teaching his victims the value of life, a deranged, sadistic serial killer abducts the morally wayward. Once captured, they must face impossible choices in a horrific game of survival. The victims must fight to win their lives back, or die trying…

end.title: Aquaman
end.creator_credit: Charles Roven, Deborah Snyder, Peter Safran, Rob Cowan, Zack Snyder, Cruel & Unusual Films, DC Films and Panoramic Pictures
end.headline_credit: Australia and United States of America, 2018
end.brief_description: Once home to the most advanced civilization on Earth, Atlantis is now an underwater kingdom ruled by the power-hungry King Orm. With a vast army at his disposal, Orm plans to conquer the remaining oceanic people and then the surface world. Standing in his way is Arthur Curry, Orm’s half-human, half-Atlantean brother and true heir to the throne.

constellations_primary.name: Aquaman VFX
constellations_primary.description: As well as becoming a global box-office sensation, Aquaman (2018) featured groundbreaking visual effects from Australian companies such as Method Studios.

constellations_other.name: Australians on the world stage
constellations_other.description: George Miller’s Mad Max revolutionised movies when it tore through cinemas in 1979. Max Rockatansky’s journey dispensing justice across the wasteland in his V8 Interceptor became a cult classic and catapulted Australian cinema onto the world stage.

links.description: After Saw, Wan kept making horror films, including establishing The Conjuring universe, but he also helmed Aquaman, one of the only critically acclaimed adaptations of a DC Comics property, which also has an Australian connection from being filmed on the Gold Coast.

end.title: The Invisible Man
end.creator_credit: Leigh Whannell, Emily Seresin, Jason Blum, Kylie du Fresne, Blumhouse Productions, Goalpost Pictures, Government of Australia, Nervous Tick, Screen Australia, The New South Wales Government, Universal Pictures and Alex Holmes
end.headline_credit: Australia and United States of America, 2020
end.brief_description: When Cecilia’s abusive ex takes his own life and leaves her his fortune, she suspects his death was a hoax. As a series of coincidences turn lethal, Cecilia works to prove that she is being hunted by someone nobody can see.

links.description: Wan’s take on Aquaman, who he thought people saw as a “kind of joke”, gave him a lot of freedom to imagine the hero how he wanted. Whannell took inspiration from this approach when making The Invisible Man, about another less popular character from Universal’s monster pantheon.

end.title: Top of the Lake
end.creator_credit: Escapade Pictures, Screen Australia and See-Saw Films
end.brief_description: A woman haunted by her past, Detective Robin Griffin, investigates complex and unsettling cases.

constellations_other.name: The drama and nuance of silhouette
constellations_other.description: Ali Gumillya Baker uses silhouette to evocative effect in her work reimagining the colonial gaze. The lighting technique has long been employed by filmmakers for its ability to dramatically convey a wide variety of emotions in everything from film noir to animation and whimsy.

links.description: Elizabeth Moss may best be known for playing Peggy in Mad Men and Offred in The Handmaid’s Tale, but another masterful turn on the small screen was in Jane Campion’s series Top of the Lake.

start.title: My Brilliant Career
start.creator_credit: Gillian Armstrong
start.credit_line:
Courtesy Margaret Fink Films

Held in the collection of the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
start.brief_description: A key work in the Australian New Wave film movement, My Brilliant Career was Gillian Armstrong’s first feature film and a global success, gaining Academy Award and Palme d’Or nominations.

constellations_primary.name: Page to screen
constellations_primary.description: Australian scribes and screenwriters unite on the silver and small screens.

constellations_other.name: Australians on the world stage
constellations_other.description: George Miller’s Mad Max revolutionised movies when it tore through cinemas in 1979. Max Rockatansky’s journey dispensing justice across the wasteland in his V8 Interceptor became a cult classic and catapulted Australian cinema onto the world stage.

constellations_other.name: Brilliant careers (Gillian Armstrong)
constellations_other.description: Gillian Armstrong's feature film debut not only helped launch her own acclaimed career, but those of the actors as well.

end.title: Mystery Road
end.creator_credit: David Jowsey and Greer Simpkin
end.brief_description: When there is a mysterious disappearance on an outback cattle station, Detective Jay Swan is assigned to investigate. Working with local cop Emma James, Jay’s investigation uncovers a past injustice that threatens the fabric of the whole community.

constellations_other.name: Native Tongue
constellations_other.description: The lead single off her album of the same name, 'Native Tongue' saw artist Mo'Ju explore cultural identity through music, movement and striking visuals.

constellations_other.name: Australians on the world stage
constellations_other.description: George Miller’s Mad Max revolutionised movies when it tore through cinemas in 1979. Max Rockatansky’s journey dispensing justice across the wasteland in his V8 Interceptor became a cult classic and catapulted Australian cinema onto the world stage.

links.description: My Brilliant Career also launched star Judy Davis’ career. After next staring in other Australian New Wave films, she went on to roles in Hollywood and round the world, earning praise and numerous major awards. Most recently Davis was back in Australia screens in Mystery Road.

start.title: The Mad Max film series
start.brief_description: George Miller’s Mad Max revolutionised movies when it tore through cinemas in 1979. Mad Max’s super-powered vehicles, legendary characters and post-apocalyptic setting influenced everything from movies, manga and music videos to fashion, videogames and art, spawning enough parodies, homages and clones to fill a Thunderdome.

constellations_primary.name: Australians on the world stage
constellations_primary.description: George Miller’s Mad Max revolutionised movies when it tore through cinemas in 1979. Max Rockatansky’s journey dispensing justice across the wasteland in his V8 Interceptor became a cult classic and catapulted Australian cinema onto the world stage.

constellations_other.name: George Miller
constellations_other.description: For a guy who started his career as a physician, George Miller sure is a diverse filmmaker.

end.title: Ngura Pukulpa – Happy Place
end.creator_credit: Kaylene Whiskey
end.credit_line:
Kaylene Whiskey, Anangu Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara Lands
Single-channel video, 8 mins
Commissioned by Melbourne Art Foundation in partnership with ACMI
end.headline_credit: Anangu Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara (APY) Lands, South Australia, Australia, 2021
end.brief_description: Yankunytjatjara artist Kaylene Whiskey’s signature pop culture figures fly from the canvas in her latest work, Ngura Pukulpa – Happy Place. Whiskey joins them, taking centrestage as a dancing queen with an entourage of seven kungka kunpu (strong women) from her community in Indulkana.

constellations_other.name: Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls
constellations_other.description: Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls explores the reality of living in Mparntwe (Alice Springs) through the eyes of the artists, who grew up there. Place and Indigenous representation are also vital to the other works in this Constellation.

constellations_other.name: Australians on the world stage
constellations_other.description: George Miller’s Mad Max revolutionised movies when it tore through cinemas in 1979. Max Rockatansky’s journey dispensing justice across the wasteland in his V8 Interceptor became a cult classic and catapulted Australian cinema onto the world stage.

links.description: Yankunytjatjara artist Kaylene Whiskey has been inspired by the Mad Max films, particularly Beyond Thunderdome and Tina Turner. The landscapes in the films remind her of her community in Indulkana, which she celebrates in her new work Ngura Pukulpa – Happy Place
